head.title: Three Indicted in Slaying Of Abducted Queens Man

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New Jersey

hedline.hl1: Three Indicted in Slaying Of Abducted Queens Man

abstract.p: New Jersey grand jury indicts Bienvenido Casilla, Juan Machado and Tony Mota on racketeering, kidnapping, murder and arson charges in Dec 13, 1997 shooting of Eriberto Acevedo of Queens, NY, whose remains were found in trunk of burning car in Harrison, NJ; Casilla and Machado were arrested in April, but Mota remains at large (S)

block.p: A state grand jury has indicted three men on racketeering, kidnapping, murder and arson charges in the shooting of a Queens man whose remains were found in the trunk of a burning car in Harrison last year, the authorities said.

According to the 15-count indictment returned on Thursday, Bienvenido Casilla, 38, of Newark; Juan Machado, 28, of Manhattan, and Tony Mota, 38, of the Bronx, kidnapped Eriberto Acevedo, 38, on Dec. 13 because he owed them money. Mr. Acevedo's family paid a ransom that included $23,000, a watch and a car, but the kidnappers did not release Mr. Acevedo. His remains were discovered three days later in the car on Route 280, the indictment said.

A state grand jury has indicted three men on racketeering, kidnapping, murder and arson charges in the shooting of a Queens man whose remains were found in the trunk of a burning car in Harrison last year, the authorities said.

According to the 15-count indictment returned on Thursday, Bienvenido Casilla, 38, of Newark; Juan Machado, 28, of Manhattan, and Tony Mota, 38, of the Bronx, kidnapped Eriberto Acevedo, 38, on Dec. 13 because he owed them money. Mr. Acevedo's family paid a ransom that included $23,000, a watch and a car, but the kidnappers did not release Mr. Acevedo. His remains were discovered three days later in the car on Route 280, the indictment said.
Mr. Casilla and Mr. Machado were arrested in April but Mr. Mota remains at large, said Chuck Davis, a spokesman for the State Attorney General's office.
If convicted, the men face fines ranging from $1.2 million to $1.45 million and sentences of between 125 and 143 years in prison.
Christopher M. DiLorenzo, a lawyer for Mr. Casilla, said his client would plead not guilty at an arraignment scheduled for Oct. 19.
